papers.abstract: This paper introduces and evaluates the project Open Arabic Periodical Editions (OpenArabicPE) as a case study of minimal computing. It confronts hyperbolic promises of mass digitization and computational methods for the exploration of digitized cultural heritage as a hegemonic episteme rooted in 20th-century, English-speaking, neoliberal capitalism from the margins. OpenArabicPE is a framework for open, collaborative, and scholarly digital editions of early Arabic periodicals from the late Ottoman Eastern Mediterranean. It addresses the specific affordances of a historical multilingual society, whose material heritage continues to be looted, destroyed, and neglected; whose material heritage resists digitization efforts by being dependent on non-Latin scripts and, for instance, non-Gregorian calendars; and whose contemporary heirs cannot draw on the vast resources in wealth and socio-technical infrastructures of the Global North. Centered around generosity and minimal computing, OpenArabicPE is run by volunteers and currently hosts six editions with some 630 journal issues and more than 7 million words, without any funding, by re-purposing data, software, and infrastructures.

events.Text: This paper introduces and evaluates the project Open Arabic Periodical Editions (OpenArabicPE) as a case study of minimal computing. It confronts hyperbolic promises of mass digitization and computational methods for the exploration of digitized cultural heritage as a hegemonic episteme rooted in 20th-century, English-speaking, neoliberal capitalism from the margins.

Context: as a hegmonic episteme rooted in 20th-century, English-speaking, neoliberal capitalism
Purpose: to demonstrate minimal computing practices concerning digital cultural heritage
Method: applying computational methods such as machine learning algorithms across various domains including corpus linguistics, historical texts analysis, and language processing tasks.
Results: successful completion of its initial objectives through evaluations conducted over three years
Analysis: contradictions between the optimism surrounding big data and the reality of resource limits and material sparsity.
implications for the applicability of similar approaches in other languages and regions.
Challenge: resource scarcity and material accessibility issues
reliance on traditional linguistic models instead of modern natural language processing advancements
Ethical: ethical concerns relating to equitable distribution and accountability in digitization projects.
Implications: broader applications of comparable methodologies in other languages and regions.

events.Text: OpenArabicPE is a framework for open, collaborative, and scholarly digital editions of early Arabic periodicals from the late Ottoman Eastern Mediterranean. It addresses the specific affordances of a historical multilingual society, whose material heritage continues to be looted, destroyed, and neglected; whose material heritage resists digitization efforts by being dependent on non-Latin scripts and, for instance, non-Gregorian calendars; and whose contemporary heirs cannot draw on the vast resources in wealth and socio-technical infrastructures of the Global North.

Primary Object: early Arabic periodicals from the late Ottoman Eastern Mediterranean

events.Text: Centered around generosity and minimal computing, OpenArabicPE is run by volunteers and currently hosts six editions with some 630 journal issues and more than 7 million words, without any funding, by re-purposing data, software, and infrastructures.

Context: without any funding, by re-purposing data, software, and infrastructures
Purpose: no funding, by re-purposing data, software, and infrastructures
Results: six editions with some 630 journal issues and more than 7 million words
Ethical: relying solely on volunteer efforts raises ethical concerns regarding sustainability and recognition
Implications: broad significance and potential for future applications/research

papers.abstract: In this paper, we present our preliminary reflections on whether minimal computing as a practice can extend beyond “computing done under some technological constraints” to served as a common ground between different digital humanities research dynamics in the Global North and South. We explore this question by commenting on our experience in developing and teaching an undergraduate course to students enrolled from both the University of Maryland, College Park in the United States and Universidad del Salvador in Buenos Aires, Argentina. The class was delivered for its first iteration in September–November 2020 and introduced students to digital publishing and textual scholarship of bilingual Spanish and English texts, presenting minimal computing as a shared set of values including: use of open technologies, ownership of data and code, and reduction in computing infrastructure.

events.Text: In this paper, we present our preliminary reflections on whether minimal computing as a practice can extend beyond 'computing done under some technological constraints' to serve as a common ground between different digital humanities research dynamics in the Global North and South.

Context: moving beyond 'computing done under some technological constraints'
to serve as a common ground between different digital humanities research dynamics in the Global North and South
Results: insights into how minimal computing extends across boundaries
Analysis: interpretation of these findings as contributions to understanding disparities in computational practices across hemispheres
Implications: extension of minimal computing could influence policy changes aimed at promoting equity in education and development sectors worldwide

events.Text: We explore this question by commenting on our experience in developing and teaching an undergraduate course to students enrolled from both the University of Maryland, College Park in the United States and Universidad del Salvador in Buenos Aires, Argentina. The class was delivered for its first iteration in September–November 2020 and introduced students to digital publishing and textual scholarship of bilingual Spanish and English texts, presenting minimal computing as a shared set of values including: use of open technologies, ownership of data and code, and reduction in computing infrastructure.
